description: Dive into "Trails of Discovery in Malaga's Mountains" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Trails of Discovery in Malaga's Mountains

places.generalDescription: Montes de M√°laga is a stunning natural park located just 5km north of Malaga city. Spanning nearly 5,000 hectares and reaching heights of over 1,000 meters, it offers panoramic views across the surrounding nature reserve. The park features lush mountains, pine-topped hills, babbling streams, and diverse flora and fauna including eagles, wild boars, and chameleons.

sources.snippet: The Montes de M√°lagaNatural Park (Parque Natural de los Montes de M√°laga) is one of the richest natural spaces and close to the urban centre. Although many locals come to this area in search of its famous ‚Äòventas‚Äô or roadside eateries, where you can try the most typical local cuisine, like ‚Äòmigas‚Äô which is a traditional dish made using old bread and exquisite ingredients, brothy rice (arroz caldoso) or the famous ‚Äòplato de los montes‚Äô which literally means ‚Äòdish from the mountains‚Äô, an increasing number of people choose to lose themselves along its hiking trails to enjoy the views offered by this natural park which has been repopulated with more than 5000 pine trees.

This a natural park with gorgeous hills, mountains and hiking trails of various levels of difficulty: it‚Äôs one of the best places to go hiking in Malaga. Another beautiful park is El Torcal, which is located a bit more inland: the karst landscape is stunning there. Adding to this, there are some beautiful villages scattered around the province, so any trip to this part of the country is worthwile.
sources.shortName: 10 Fabulous Places To Go Hiking In Malaga And Its Province

places.name: Montes de M√°laga

reviews.text: Nice place to visit, perfect camina for dog-walk. We did not have such a nice weather, but still was really nice.
The perfect observation deck in Malaga
Really beautiful, perfect for a stroll, hiking, bike riding, horse riding and much more

places.generalDescription: Montes de M√°laga Natural Park, located just 5 kilometers north of the city of Malaga, is a vast natural paradise with a rich history dating back to prehistoric times. This 4,996-hectare park was once used for timber production and agriculture and is now considered the "lung" of the surrounding areas.

sources.snippet: No more than an hour away of the city centre you can enjoy nature at its best in the Natural Reserve of the Montes de Malaga. There is a good number of routes to enjoy in the forest paths that join three key points: Aula de las Contadoras, Lagar de Torrijos and Mirador del Cochino.

places.name: Montes de M√°laga Natural Park

reviews.text: A walk in the hills which at any time of the year affords clean air and stunning views, and in May and June floral displays which are glorious. Follow the Malaga road out of Colemenar until you encounter the bar Venta Pinar and a saw mill. Park behind the pub. The walk starts there.

We were quite surprised by how unsuited for cars the roads were as soon as we entered the park (not that it's a bad thing, just surprising). We drove some kilometers into the park anyway, parked the car and proceeded by foot. The park itself is great for hiking and the nature in there is nice, clean and untouched - I'm sure in part due to its less approachable nature :) The park is well worth a visit, and walks can be done by people of all ages - we even brought 3 small kids and a stroller..

Looking for a day away from the hustle and bustle of the beach and city. Montes de Malaga is wonderful retreat to nature. Lose yourself on the numerous pathways and cycle routes. Enjoy panoramic views from quaint, rustic cafes and restaurants along the main road. A perfect place for nature lovers.

sources.shortName: The Best Hiking Routes Around the City

places.name: Entrada Sur a Monte San Anton

reviews.text: A bit arduous hike(the circuitous road is really steep before you reach the foot of the mountain) and the way up to the top is unruly so be utmost cautious and take baby steps. However a few slips and falls(well out of our 5 member team only one person fell down and it was unsurprisingly me as I was too busy absorbing the surreal surrounding) are all worthwhile once you reach the top. It has one of the best views of Malaga city from the topmost point and the sunset view is out of the world, breathtakingly spectacular.
As other mentioned, this is probably an underrated hike! It's pretty close to malaga! Easy to park in the streets in near the entrance ( when empty )

Beautiful but challgenging hike (not for the lighthearted really)....very nice view up top....but be VERY careful - there are multiple paths that may be going somewhere or nowhere so if you're going by youself try to follow a group. I followed a group on my way up but on the way down I walked down a path that looked reasonable...until i realized it wasn't a path but a very hard downhill way but it was too late to go back. After a lot of slips, fall and scrutches and as the sun was about to set i reached the road...so be VERY mindful of where you're going and try to follow people who know their way around..

places.address: Av. San Ant√≥n, 118, M√°laga-Este, 29018 M√°laga, Spain

places.generalDescription: Monte Coronado offers a longer and more challenging route compared to Monte San Anton. The area provides a wild and secluded atmosphere with stunning views of Malaga city and the surrounding mountains. The landscape is characterized by massive rocks, resembling a canyon, creating an incredible and unique setting that is definitely worth exploring. Despite its moderate difficulty, the hike rewards visitors with a beautiful cliff vantage point overlooking the entire city.

sources.snippet: Monte Coronado is a longer route and a bit more challenging with Monte San Anton being the most challenging of all.
sources.shortName: Hiking Malaga (with the help of a bike!)

places.name: Monte Coronado

reviews.text: Wild place with a great view to M√°laga city and mountains on other side. There are almost no people. Rocks on the top are huge, place in general looks like a canyon. Absolutely crazy and incredible landscape, totally worth to visit. Pretty easy climbing, about 30 min from the city center.

a good walk from the city centre... not too steep until you get to the rocks... the surrounding residential area is a dump with dog crap and fly tipping everywhere... but the hills are decent and you'll see wild horses and a herd of mountain goats... the rocks themselves can be climbed without gear.. wear decent walking shoes and you'll be fine... views from the top make it all worthwhile... I went on a sunny Friday afternoon in February and there was no one there except for the goat herder.

A moderate hike to a beautiful cliff overlooking the entire city. Don't really need a lot of experience hiking to make it up but bringing lots of water is a great idea. Really won't regret anything with the view you will get.

places.address: Av. de Valle-Incl√°n, Palma-Palmilla, 29010 M√°laga, Spain

places.generalDescription: Mirador de Pocop√°n is a popular spot in the park, offering breathtaking views of Malaga from the beach to the quaint towns inland. The trail leading to it can be challenging, with loose stones and steep slopes, but the panoramic vistas at the top make it all worthwhile. This two-kilometer trek is not for the faint-hearted, as it involves an adventurous climb up a hill without a defined path.

sources.snippet: Located in the Sierras de Tejeda, Almijara y Alhama Natural Park, La Maroma‚Äôs summit offers breathtaking views of the Mediterranean Sea. You can access it from a variety of different hiking trails, but one of the most popular ones is El Robeldal Trail. It starts from the Alhama de Granada, a mountain area between the provinces of Malaga and Granada, and takes about four to seven hours to complete, depending on how fast of a hiker you are‚Äîand how many times you stop to take photos!

places.name: Mirador de Pocop√°n

reviews.text: Amazing view, it costs nothing to visit the place.
Beautiful walk through woods and on trails. Steep last 300m, but you can walk round to the other side and take a (slightly) more gentle climb to the mirador.
Very steep 300meters, but worths the climbing :) you can also meet some goats üêê

places.generalDescription: The Gran Senda de M√°laga is a 739 km long walking trail that spans the rugged province of Malaga, consisting of 35 stages. Along the route, hikers can explore picturesque white towns like Casares in the Serrania de Ronda mountains and enjoy stunning natural landscapes with deep gorges and rough waters. The trail offers a perfect opportunity for families to experience sunny beaches even in December, with temperatures ranging from 16 to 20 degrees Celsius.

sources.snippet: If you fancy even more active tourism, there are many companies that organise water activities in the reservoirs nearby, or you can walk part of the Gran Senda de M√°laga path. But if you prefer something more urban and cultural (or a dip in the sea, depending on the time of year), don't forget that the city of Malaga is less than 50 kilometres away.

places.name: Gran Senda de M√°laga

reviews.text: Calm beautiful and sunny beach in December....Perfect gateway for family with kids in Decembef time....Temp. ranges between 16 to 20 Dec.C
We walked this beautiful path in winter, had a grest time on the way, got to know so many people
Well marked from Malaga to the entrance to Almayate, but no more markings visible immediately after the entrance to A.?

places.address: C/ Pac√≠fico, 54, Carretera de C√°diz, 29004 M√°laga, Spain
